data.title: Nazi officer Wilm Hosenfeld who saved 'The Pianist' Władysław Szpilman
data.meta_description: Nazi officer Wilm Hosenfeld idolised 'true genius' Hitler, but became horrified by atrocities he witnessed in Warsaw and vowed to help who I can', including pianist Władysław Szpilman.
data.text:
The pianist Władysław Szpilman, half-crazed, half-starved and seemingly doomed to be rounded up and gassed in a Nazi death factory like the rest of his family - crawled into the house in the moonscape of Warsaw in 1944 to die.

He had lived through unspeakable horrors during the German occupation. Huddled in the freezing shell of 223 Niepodległości Avenue, salvation came at the last moment in an unlikely form - an officer of the regime that had exterminated his family, along with six million other Jews.

Wilm Hosenfeld, bearer of the Iron Cross First Class for gallantry in the First World War, was a Nazi officer who, in that shell-pocked house, forgot the Fuehrer he once idolised and the regime he promised to serve faithfully unto death.

He discovered his humanity and saved the talented pianist Szpilman by bringing him food and keeping his survival secret from S.S. death squads roaming the ruins of the Polish capital.

Scroll down for video

The meeting, the story, was immortalised in the 2003 Roman Polanski film 'The Pianist' which won three academy awards.

Produced by Polanski, Robert Benmussa and Alain Sarde, the screenplay by Ronald Harwood, The Pianist won Oscars for best director, best actor, and best adapted screenplay.

Hosenfeld, as portrayed in the movie by actor Thomas Kretschmer, was a one-dimensional figure with a small part. Now comes his true moment in the spotlight with a fascinating biography that unveils the deep humanity of this religious and humble officer sickened by the atrocities he witnessed during the Nazi rule of Poland.

Far from being a one-off act, the book 'I Always See The Human Being Before Me', by Hermann Vinke, shows that the man who hailed Adolf Hitler as a 'true genius' in 1940 rediscovered his own conscience long before the war was over.

The book is the first about Hosenfeld and draws on letters, diaries, memories from his children and even the widow of Szpilman who still lives in Warsaw, to show that his act of mercy towards the pianist was no one-off affair.

'His moral and ethical compass remained intact during the war,' said author Vinke, whose book has been received to great critical acclaim.

'Hosenfeld did not only save Szpilman but numerous other Polish citizens, among them other Jews, from a certain death.

'Against the backdrop of murder and deathly blows this officer was like a lighthouse in a time of darkness. Probably there were over 60 people who owed their lives directly to him. He was both saviour and in some ways a victim because he could not save himself in the end from death in a Soviet prison without ever seeing his family again.'

This Nazi officer, honoured only in the last few years as one of the 'Righteous Among The Nations' - a non-Jew who saved Jews - by Israel, was an unlikely hero and saviour. A pious Catholic, he was brought up in the strict martial code of Prussia to unthinkingly obey orders.

First he pledged his loyalty to Kaiser Wilhelm II, later to Adolf HItler, Fuehrer of the Greater German Reich. An oath of loyalty sworn by such men was almost physically real and, to break it, almost unthinkable.

Hosenfeld joined the Nazi Party in 1935, one of those millions of Germans who saw in Hitler and his party the chance to wipe clean the shame of 1918 and the collapse of Imperial Germany. With his brother Rudolf her marched with 500,000 men at the pompous Nuremberg Rally of 1936.

'The new battlefield weapons were displayed. Tank and anti-tank weapons, planes.' 'The spectacle excited me,' he confided to his diary.

Enthusiastically he would síng the Horst Wessel Lied, the Nazi party hymn to a brownshirted thug of the same name who was the movement's first martyr. 'Over all of Germany is his name known!' he wrote. 'All march with him and my heart marches too.'

It is clear that, at the beginning, Hosenfeld had nothing but admiration for the New Germany and all its works. But as he witnessed more and more Nazi events and sensed the hollowness and menace of its doctrine, the scales began to fall from his eyes. 'The futility of it all grows ever more in my consciousness,' he wrote in 1938. But he remained spellbound by Hitler.

By 1939, shortly before the invasion of Poland, he was once again in uniform in his birthplace Fulda. His wife Annemarie was upset that, at the age of 44, he might be marching off to war again.

And soon he was, pouring over the border with the legions who would turn Poland into a slaughterhouse and slave market. He would spend the entire war there.

His first destination was Pabianice, where he was involved in the building and running of a POW camp. Next, he was stationed in Węgrów in December 1939, where he remained until his battalion was moved another 30 km away to Jadów at the end of May 1940. He was finally transferred to Warsaw in July 1940, where he spent the rest of the war, for the most part attached to a guards battalion in which he served as a staff officer and as the battalion sports officer.

Hitler had nothing but contempt for Poland and its people. Those he didn't kill he enslaved. No country suffered as much durng WW2 - three million citizens murdered, most of its major cities decimated - and Hosenfeld lived and breathed the carnage on a daily basis.

When he housed the first starving, mistreated Polish prisoners he was shocked at their condition and wrote to his wife: 'I think people look and see that I suffer with them. It is pitiful to see these poor men, their miserable state, but we are powerless. But I seek to help who I can.'

It was the first breach in the wall of Nazi orthodoxy that would ultimately lead to the salvation of Władysław Szpilman.

'Between his personal conduct and his political attitude towards the Nazi regime opened up a gap which grew ever larger,' said Vinke, a respected historian and Third Reich expert.

It began with the distribution of apples and nuts to malnourished Polish POWs in his care. Then he released some without authority from superiors. One Polish woman stuffed a 20 Zloty note into his hand because he let go her husband and two sons.

Before long he witnessed up close the terror unleashed on the local population by the Einsatzgruppen - the Action Squads of the S.S. - who murdered wholesale. In one letter home to Annemarie dated November 10 1939, just two months after the invasion, he wrote: 'A powerless anger, a terrible shriek comes from house after house where a Pole lives.'

He told his wife that he was wearing the uniform of criminals and said that 'I met with many soldiers, railway officials, officers. One said: 'One is ashamed to be a German.''

At Lodz, where Germany established one of the largest Jewish ghettos in Poland, he told his wife he witnessed children being loaded into cattle wagons 'like cattle themselves.'

During his time in Warsaw, Hosenfeld used his position to save a variety of people, regardless of their background, including at least one anti-Nazi ethnic German in danger of arrest by the Gestapo.

For some he procured false papers they needed and jobs at the sports stadium that was under his command.

Once, when riding a bicycle near the Polish town of Pabiance, Hosenfeld had encountered a young Jewish woman running desperately down the road.

What cowards we are, wanting to be better and allowing all this to happen. For this, we too will be punished, and our innocent children after us, because in allowing these evil deeds to occur, we are partners to the guilt.

When he asked her where she was going, she told Hosenfeld that she was pregnant and that her husband was a prisoner in a nearby concentration camp.

She was going to the camp to beg for his release. Hosenfeld wrote down the husband's name and said to the wife, 'Your husband will be home again in three days.'

He kept his word.

Another day, Hosenfeld had learned that the Gestapo had rounded up a number of men, including the brother-in-law of a priest who was in the Polish underground.

They were being taken by truck to a labour camp, and the brother-in-law was to be executed. Hosenfeld spotted the truck moving through town, waved it down, and told the S.S. officer, 'I need a man' for labour detail and picked out the priest's brother-in-law, as if by random. He survived the war.

The biggest crime of all, Hosenfeld soon realised, was the Warsaw Ghetto, the stinking, crammed prison for Warsaw's Jews where they were to be held before shipment north to the extermination camp of Treblinka where a million would be gassed and burned.

When he learned of the Holocaust taking place he wrote: 'It is impossible to believe all these things, even though they are true. Yesterday I saw two of these beasts (s.s. men) in the tram. They were holding whips in their hands when they came out of the ghetto. I would like to throw those dogs under the tram. What cowards we are, wanting to be better and allowing all this to happen. For this, we too will be punished, and our innocent children after us, because in allowing these evil deeds to occur, we are partners to the guilt.'

These animals. With horrible mass murder of the Jews we have lost this war. We have brought an eternal curse on ourselves and will be forever covered with shame.

A Jew called Leon Warm escaped from a train to Treblinka during the 1942 deportations from Warsaw. He made it back into the city, and managed to survive with the help of Hosenfeld who employed him in the sports stadium under the false identity Warczynski. After the war, Warm was one of those who pleaded for Russia to release his saviour.

Hosenfeld risked his life, and that of his family, with both his diary and his letters home in which he liked to tell Annemarie of the small victories he had achieved over the Nazi butchers.

In 1943, after witnessing the suppression of the Warsaw Ghetto revolt when ever last Jew was either killed in the uprising or deported to the gas chambers, he wrote in his diary: 'These animals. With horrible mass murder of the Jews we have lost this war. We have brought an eternal curse on ourselves and will be forever covered with shame. We have no right for compassion or mercy; we all have a share in the guilt. I am ashamed to walk in the city.

'These brutes think we shall win the war that way. But we have lost the war with this appalling mass murder of the Jews. We have brought shame upon ourselves that cannot be wiped out; it is a curse that cannot be lifted. We deserve no mercy; we are all guilty ...'

The Third Reich had just another two years left to run, but it was time enough for Hosenfeld to witness cruelty piled on cruelty by his countrymen.

And so, as he struggled to perform acts of salvation, Hosenfeld came to the house in Niepodległości Avenue where he would rescue the classical pianist whose family had gone 'up the chimney' at Treblinka.

Szpilman, after the war, pleaded with Polish communist officials to get the Soviets to release him. He was captured with his men at Błonie, a small Polish city about 30km west of Warsaw, and sentenced to 25 years for spying.

In a 1946 letter to his wife in West Germany, Hosenfeld named the Jews whom he had saved and begged her to contact them and ask them to arrange his release.

But he suffered terribly in Russian captivity, though torture, overwork and malnutrition. Wehrmacht Captain Wilm Hosenfeld died in a Soviet concentration camp on 13 August 1952, rupture of the thoracic aorta probably sustained during torture.
